verses.text: Say to your brothers, "You are my people," and to your sisters, "You have received mercy."
verses.comment: Unlike the harsher judgments earlier, this verse opens with a promise of mercy and restoration, anticipating the full reconciliation of God with his people. Paul cites this in Romans and Peter in 1 Peter, affirming the inclusive call to salvation made in Christ.

verses.text: Plead with your mother, plead—because she is not my wife, and I am not her husband—so that she may put away her adultery from her face and her promiscuity from between her breasts.
verses.comment: Israel is depicted as an unfaithful wife, a common prophetic metaphor for idolatry and spiritual infidelity (cf. Jeremiah 3:8). This language foreshadows the Church as the renewed and faithful Bride of Christ.

verses.text: Otherwise, I will strip her naked and expose her as on the day of her birth; I will make her like a wilderness, and turn her into a dry land, and kill her with thirst.
verses.comment: God's judgment is just but aims at correction, not destruction. The stripping imagery echoes Ezekiel 16, underscoring the seriousness of abandoning the covenant.

verses.text: I will not have mercy on her children, for they are children of unfaithfulness.
verses.comment: The consequences of Israel’s spiritual infidelity extend to the next generation, highlighting the far-reaching effects of sin. Yet, persistent hope of reconciliation will emerge later in the chapter.

verses.text: Because their mother has been unfaithful; she who conceived them has acted shamefully. For she said, 'I will go after my lovers, who give me my bread and my water, my wool and my flax, my oil and my drink.'
verses.comment: This is a powerful indictment against Israel attributing prosperity to foreign gods and political alliances rather than to God, paralleling the Israelites’ idolatry of Baal.

verses.text: Therefore, I will hedge her way with thorns, and I will build a wall against her, so that she cannot find her paths.
verses.comment: God disciplines to lead the unfaithful back—by blocking sinful paths, He hopes to guide Israel to repentance, as with the discipline of a loving Father.

verses.text: She will chase after her lovers but will not overtake them. She will seek them but will not find them. Then she will say, 'I will go and return to my first husband, for it was better for me then than now.'
verses.comment: This verse echoes the prodigal son (Luke 15:17), emphasizing the grace always available for repentance and return to God. Literal and spiritual return is thus encouraged.

verses.text: She did not know that it was I who gave her the grain, the wine, and the oil, and multiplied for her silver and gold, which they used for Baal.
verses.comment: God is the true source of all blessings. Reminds one of Deut. 8, which warns against forgetting the Lord even in prosperity.

verses.text: Therefore I will take back my grain in its time, and my wine in its season, and I will withdraw my wool and my flax, which were to cover her nakedness.
verses.comment: Divine provision is never to be presumed upon. When used for idolatry, God withdraws His gifts as loving discipline.

verses.text: Now I will uncover her lewdness in the sight of her lovers, and no one shall rescue her from my hand.
verses.comment: No external power—political or spiritual—can rescue from God’s just chastisement.

verses.text: I will also put an end to all her joy, her feasts, her new moons, her Sabbaths, and all her appointed festivals.
verses.comment: Even religious celebrations become empty if hearts are far from God. See also Isaiah 1:13-14.

verses.text: And I will lay waste her vines and her fig trees, of which she said, 'These are my wages, that my lovers have given me.' I will make them a forest, and the beasts of the field shall devour them.
verses.comment: The loss of abundance points to the futility of seeking fulfillment apart from God. Compare with the warning of the vineyard in Isaiah 5.

verses.text: I will punish her for the days of the Baals when she burned offerings to them and adorned herself with rings and jewelry, and went after her lovers and forgot me, declares the LORD.
verses.comment: This mirrors the golden calf sin (Exodus 32), showing the seriousness of spiritual adultery and forgetfulness of God’s saving acts.

verses.text: Therefore, behold, I will allure her, and bring her into the wilderness, and speak tenderly to her.
verses.comment: God’s response to infidelity is surprising grace—He woos back Israel as He did after the Exodus, echoing the intimacy of the Song of Songs.

verses.text: I will give her vineyards from there, and the Valley of Achor as a door of hope. There she will answer as in the days of her youth, as at the time when she came out of the land of Egypt.
verses.comment: ‘Valley of Achor,’ a place of trouble, becomes hope—a profound symbol of redemption and restoration. God turns judgment into new beginnings.

verses.text: And in that day, declares the LORD, you will call me 'My Husband,' and you will no longer call me 'My Master.'
verses.comment: The relationship will become intimate and familial, not formal or distant. The language anticipates the New Covenant, the union of Christ and the Church.

verses.text: For I will remove the names of the Baals from her mouth, and they shall be remembered by name no more.
verses.comment: God purifies His people, restoring them to worship of the one true LORD. Idolatry will be eradicated completely.

verses.text: In that day I will make for them a covenant on their behalf with the beasts of the field, and the birds of the sky, and the creeping things of the ground. And I will abolish the bow, the sword, and war from the land, and I will make them lie down in safety.
verses.comment: This universal peace recalls Isaiah 11 and Ezekiel 34—a foretaste of the messianic age where all creation is renewed in harmony under God’s kingdom.

verses.text: And I will betroth you to myself forever; I will betroth you to myself in righteousness, and in justice, in steadfast love, and in mercy.
verses.comment: God's unending covenant is described as a bridal bond—forever. This points forward to the indissoluble union between God and His redeemed people.

verses.text: I will betroth you to myself in faithfulness, and you shall know the LORD.
verses.comment: To genuinely know the LORD reflects the intimate knowledge anticipated in the New Covenant (Jeremiah 31). Knowing is experiential and relational, not merely intellectual.

verses.text: And in that day I will answer, declares the LORD, I will answer the heavens, and they shall answer the earth;
verses.comment: God restores cosmic harmony—healing the relation between heaven and earth, which recalls the blessings of creation and covenant fulfillment.

verses.text: And the earth shall answer the grain, the wine, and the oil, and they shall answer Jezreel.
verses.comment: Jezreel, once a sign of judgment, now becomes a symbol of fruitfulness and renewed blessing, reversing the earlier curse (see Hosea 1:4).

verses.text: I will sow her for myself in the land. I will have mercy on 'No Mercy,' and I will say to 'Not My People,' 'You are my people'; and he shall say, 'You are my God.'
verses.comment: The final restoration is complete. Paul (Romans 9:25–26) and Peter (1 Peter 2:10) apply this to Gentile believers—God’s mercy extends universally through faith. This foreshadows true unity among believers in the renewed covenant family adopted by grace.
